awd_titl_txt: Acquisition of a high temperature elemental analyzer for hydrogen and oxygen isotope analysis of waters and solids for the University of Cincinnati Stable Isotope Laboratory
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will expand the analytical capabilities of the University of Cincinnati (UC) UC Stable Isotope Laboratory by adding new instrumentation to measure the stable hydrogen (H) and oxygen (O) isotopic compositions of waters and solid organics. In the past few years, the research of the UC Stable Isotope Laboratory has included more focus on the hydrologic cycle and tracking the foraging habits and mobility patterns of animals over time. This work requires measurements of H and O isotopes of waters and tissues containing proteins. Expanded in-house analytical abilities made possible by this award will support and strengthen the established research programs at our laboratory as well as make possible anticipated research directions in the areas of paleoclimatology, conservation biology, paleoecology, and organic geochemistry research. H and O isotopes in water are commonly used to address a wide array of topics in the geosciences, such as characterization of the hydrologic cycle, measuring evaporation and transpiration in plants, as well as evaporation in surface waters and soils, identifying water vapor and precipitation source, and investigating groundwater infiltration and mixing. Past records of the hydrologic cycle can be generated from proxies that indirectly record precipitation and surface water H and O. Combined, these new analytical directions will improve paleo-hydrologic reconstructions and future predictions of hydrologic change. A more complete understanding of the hydrological cycle is critical for safeguarding national health, prosperity, and welfare. Additionally, H and O isotopes in organic animal tissues can be used to track foraging behavior and movement patterns of both living and historic fauna. This information complements that provided by other isotopes like carbon (C) and nitrogen (N), as well as more traditional methods for obtaining geographical information (e.g., banding or satellite-tracking individuals). Surprisingly little is known about individual mobility or population connectivity for many highly mobile and migratory animal species (e.g., birds, butterflies), and even less is known about how stable these patterns are over time. Given the rate and scale of anthropogenic changes to most of our planet’s surface, obtaining such data is increasingly urgent. 

The UC Stable Isotope Laboratory currently houses two isotope ratio mass spectrometers with the ability to analyze C and N of bulk organics, C and H of specific compounds (e.g., leaf wax n-alkanes), C and O of carbonates, C and H of atmospheric methane, and H and O of water, but with poor precision. However, there are no capabilities to measure H and O of organic solids. This award will add a high temperature elemental analyzer for the analysis of H and O of solids, including organic tissues (e.g., chitin, keratin and cellulose), and provide analysis of H and O of waters with high precision. This new instrumentation will also greatly increase sample throughput and lower labor demands. It will also provide novel hands-on analytical training in three established geology classes that serve undergraduate and graduate students taught by the investigators, as well as additional analytical opportunities to support undergraduate and graduate student research. This instrument acquisition will continue to support the strong record of mentoring students (particularly women) and providing research opportunities to students both at UC and other institutions, including primarily undergraduate institutions. Lastly, the requested instrumentation will play a critical role in expanding undergraduate capstone experiences within the UC Geology Department as part of current efforts to improve program equity and inclusion. This award will support one female PhD student and the proposed work will directly support two undergraduate student research projects to develop and test standards and methods for the new equipment. The PIs will expand their existing public engagement programs on climate change by developing a science outreach program in collaboration with Geology graduate students. The initial target venue will be a local Farmer’s Market that serves a diverse urban community, but it is anticipated that the program will evolve and expand with new cohorts of graduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award provided support for a new elemental analyzer (EA) to expand the analytical capabilities in the University of Cincinnati Stable Isotope Laboratory. This instrument is critical for ongoing and future research and broader impact efforts of the PIs.

The EA includes a high temperature pyrolysis reactor for the analysis of hydrogen and oxygen isotopes of waters and organic tissues (e.g., chitin, keratin and cellulose). The hydrogen and oxygen isotopes of waters are commonly used to address a wide array of topics in the geosciences, such as the characterization of the hydrologic cycle, measuring evaporation and transpiration in plants, evaporation in surface waters and soils, identifying water vapor and precipitation source, and investigating groundwater infiltration and mixing. Past records of the hydrologic cycle can be generated from proxies that indirectly record precipitation and surface water hydrogen and oxygen isotopes. These isotopic signals are passed up the food chain and encoded in animal tissues, which provides information about diet, habitat, and mobility. In addition, this equipment will allow us to develop compound specific isotope standards for the isotope community. Prior to this award, the lab lacked the ability to measure hydrogen and oxygen isotopes in solid samples. Our existing system for measuring water isotopes was time consuming, costly to operate, required large amounts of helium for flushing, and lacked the necessary precision. This new instrumentation eliminates these challenges.

The new EA also expands our capabilities of analyzing carbon and nitrogen isotopes of solids and adds the ability to analyze C and N in liquids. This expands our lab throughput. It also provides an advancement over our existing instrumentation by adding the ability to dilute sample gases within an analysis run while also providing elemental abundance data. This is very useful for sediment and plant samples, which can have widely variable carbon and nitrogen content. Prior to this new EA, we had to run these kinds of samples twice. We first analyzed them for their elemental abundance (to determine appropriate sample size for isotopic analysis), and then based on that amount, we would then run for isotopes. This new instrumentation allows both measurements in the same run. This will significantly reduce analysis time, conserve small samples, and make student project significantly easier to carry out. 

Expanded in-house analytical abilities strengthen and enhance the PIs’ current and future research in the areas of organic geochemistry, paleoclimatology, conservation biology, and paleoecology. In addition to supporting the PIs’ research, this new equipment will benefit other researchers at UC, within the region, and beyond, including 3 primarily undergraduate intuitions (PUIs). This equipment will considerably enhance student teaching and training through coursework as well as graduate and undergraduate student research projects that heavily rely on the Stable Isotope Laboratory. To date, the lab has supported the research of over 20 UC undergraduates, 25 graduate students, and 12 visiting students.

The new instrumentation provides novel hands-on analytical training in several established geology classes that serve undergraduate and graduate students taught by the PIs. The equipment will provide additional analytical opportunities to support undergraduate and graduate student research. The PIs have a strong record of mentoring students (particularly women) and providing research opportunities to students not only at UC, but to many visiting students from other institutions as well, including some from PUIs. To date, we have mentored over 50 student research projects. Undergraduate student research projects will expand in the coming years as our department transitions away from traditional capstone experiences like field camp to more individualized options. The requested equipment supported and trained one female PhD student, one MS student, and an undergraduate student. In addition, this award supported and trained a female undergraduate student to develop and analyze standards and to test the new instrumentation. In addition to research training, we provided mentorship and professional guidance with the goal that these students will have successful careers in the geosciences. The PIs enhanced their existing public engagement programs by expanding their science outreach program, Science Harvest, at a local Farmer’s Market that serves a diverse urban community.
